bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, March 4, 1941

div1.p: Hench informs Truby that he is planning a trip to Havana, and so would like Truby and Kean to write letters of introduction to Ramos.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, March 4, 1941
div1.opener:
3/6/41-Sent
Clippings, Come
etc
March 4, 1941
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I plan to leave Rochester about March 21 and go (via a stopover at Palm Beach)
to Havana, to be in Havana at the Hotel Nacional about the last week in March or the
first week in April. I hope to interview the owner of the shack (Building #1) and make
final arrangements for its preservation. But my immediate concern is to draft a final
copy of my report on the true location of Camp Lazear which Dr. Ramos, Minister of De-
fense, asked me to prepare. I have documented this report with about 50 exhibits
(photographs, maps and photostated letters, etc.) Because I have quoted you and Gen-
eral Kean so often I feel that I must submit a preliminary copy to you both so that
I have your approval. I am also sending Mr. Moran a copy to show to Senora Rojas and
to Senor Pogolotti. Because our photographic department is so busy at the moment I
simply haven't had the nerve to ask them to make 5 copies each of these 50 exhibits
(i.e. 250 prints) but if you will consult the list of them I think you will remember
many of them as you have either seen most of them or I have sent them to you previously.
I enclose a few prints which I don't believe you've seen. I am most anxious for your
reaction to this report. If you agree with it in general (I can't ask you to vouch
for every word I've said) would you be willing to write me a letter addressed to
His Excellency, Dr. Domingo Ramos, Minister of National Defense, Government of Cuba
and state that you have been familiar with my investigations, have helped me in much
of it, have read my report to him and can give it your general approval (or whatever
wording you think suitable). I will ask General Kean to do the same. I know that if
I can send with my report these two letters from you and General Kean he will doubtless
pay much more attention to it. But there is one hitch. I've been so busy I'm late
now in getting this report done. Could you possibly review my report at your very
earliest convenience and return it to me airmail special delivery (stamped folder
enclosed) so that I can change it as necessary and try to get it in Dr. Ramos' hands
by about March 15 so that perhaps he (or a deputy) can look it over before my arrival.

Of course I hope that the report will be accepted by Dr. Ramos and his colleagues
and that some day (manana) they may act on it. But that is one matter, and the placing
of this report on record is a more important matter. Whether they act on it or not
I shall publish a synopsis of it (with Moran and Pogolotti as co-authors) in some
American medical journal and if possible a Cuban journal also. I cannot tell you how
grateful I am for all your help.

I hope soon to answer your last letters in detail but I have to write two
medical papers in the next three weeks, one for an English journal and one for the
General Albert E. Truby
- 2 -
March 4, 1941
medical department of the War Department (a brief synopsis of current concepts on
rheumatic diseases). Since neither is started I'll have to get busy. Permit me to
send you a reprint of an article which just appeared.

closer.seg:
P. S. How soon do you want the extra copies of my W. and J. talk? As soon
as I return from Havana I will conclude arrangements to have it republished, at
which time I can send you as many reprints as you want (at no expense to you, of
course). If you want a few sooner all I can send you is photostat copies of the
talk as it appeared in the W. and J. brochure as I could get no extra copies.
You might return the report and photographs by ordinary mail at your
earliest convenience but please airmail special your comments and suggestions on
the report and the separate letter of general approval which I hope you will
address to Ramos, and send me, enclosed with the report. Unfortunately, the War
Department couldn't find the key to the 1902 map but I think I have quoted you
correctly on what you thought the little buildings to the west of the railroad
track were. In your last letter you spoke of the “1900 map” also of “the original
one in 1899-1900”. Please see enclosed a letter from me to Mr. Freer, Chief Clerk
of the Office of the Chief of Engineers, and his reply. Do you have any suggestions
as to where we could trace the map I mentioned to him and the one you mentioned
to me, or trace the key to the 1902 map? Would it do any good if you wrote to
Freer or to the Chief of the Engineers? It seems to me, however, that he has
probably done a very conscientious job of hunting.
P.S.H.
